Plasma preparation of highly reactive Ag-Cu NPs anchored in N-PC as catalysts for Aluminum-air battery Jie Wang Aimin Wu ⁎ Lei Xing Shuai Ran Wenhua Yu Xufeng Dong Hao Huang Key Laboratory of Energy Materials and Devices (Liaoning Province), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China Key Laboratory of Energy Materials and Devices (Liaoning Province) School of Materials Science and Engineering Dalian University of Technology Dalian Liaoning 116024 China Key Laboratory of Energy Materials and Devices (Liaoning Province), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The preparation of Ag-Cu25 NPs by plasma evaporation undergoes a rapid cooling process, which facilitates the formation of eutectic structures, changes the electronic structure, increases oxygen adsorption and accelerates the ORR reaction. Efficient, stable and economical catalysts play a crucial role in enhancing the kinetics of slow oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) in Aluminum-air batteries. Among the potential next-generation candidates, Ag catalysts are promising due to their high activity and low cost, but weaker oxygen adsorption has hindered industrialization. To address this bottleneck, Ag-alloying has emerged as a principal strategy. In this work, we successfully prepared Ag-Cu nanoparticles (NPs) with a rich eutectic phase and uniform dispersion structure using plasma evaporation. The increased solid solution of Ag and Cu led to changes in the electronic structure, resulting in an upward shift of the d-band center, which significantly improved oxygen adsorption. The combination of Ag and Cu in the NPs synergistically enhanced the adsorption of Ag and the desorption of Cu. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that Ag-Cu25 NPs exhibited the smallest limiting reaction barrier, leading to increased ORR activity. To further optimize the catalyst's performance, we utilized N-doped porous nanocarbon (N-PC) with high electrical conductivity and abundant mesoporous channels as the support for the Ag-Cu NPs. The N-PC support provided optimal mass transfer carriers for the highly active Ag-Cu25 NPs. As a result, the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst displayed excellent ORR activity in alkaline media, with a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.82 V. Furthermore, the Al-air battery incorporating the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst exhibited outstanding electrochemical performance. It demonstrated high open-circuit voltages of 1.89 V and remarkable power densities of 193 mW cm−2. The battery also sustained a high current output and maintained a stable high voltage for 120 hours under mechanical charging, showcasing its significant potential for practical applications. Keywords Aluminum-air battery Catalyst Ag-Cu nanoparticles Eutectic Nitrogen-doped Oxygen reduction reaction 1 Introduction Aluminum-air (Al-air) battery possesses the advantages of high energy density, low cost and easy replacement, and has great application potential in the field of standby power supply and portable power supply [1–3]. The lagging and slow oxygen reduction reaction seriously restricts the development of high-performance aluminum air batteries [4–6]. Platinum group metal (PGM) catalyst is recognized as the most advanced ORR catalyst, but its high price and low reserves limit its commercial development [7–9]. Accordingly, the development of non-PGM electrocatalysts tailored for oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) applications occupies considerable importance. Silver (lower price, roughly 4 RMB g−1) exhibits high ORR activity in the volcano plot with promising potential as a next-generation ORR candidate material [10–12]. Additionally, the superior stability of Ag in alkaline electrolytes compared to Pt is attributed to the higher equilibrium potential of Ag/Ag2O than that of Pt/PtO [13,14]. Increasing the activity of Ag (one-tenth that of Pt) remained an urgent problem [15]. Based on the intrinsic activity of the material, the enhancement of the reaction kinetics and activity of Ag should start from improving its ability to adsorb oxygen as the main design strategy [16]. Extensive research projects to regulate the d-band center of Ag concluded into three categories: morphological modulation [17–19], alloying [20,21], and compounding with carriers [22,23]. Returning to the volcano plot, the transition metal Cu with better activity and ability to adsorb oxygen has been widely focused on the preparation of Ag-Cu alloys [24]. The Ag-Cu alloying modifies its electronic structure which enhances the surface reaction activity. Density functional theory (DFT) fully demonstrates that AgCu alloys possess a strong oxygen adsorption energy and a low activation energy [25,26]. The Ag-Cu composite catalysts prepared via pulsed sputtering and cyclic scanning electrodeposition represent excellent catalytic activity [24,27]. The industrial preparation of Ag-Cu catalysts presents significant challenges, owing to the extremely weak solid solubility (<1 at%) of silver and copper. Non-equilibrium solidification is the main path towards the preparation of Ag-Cu composites with high solid solution. Moreover, the mass transfer structure plays an instrumental element in the design of excellent catalysts [28,29]. Carbon materials, offering structural diversity and excellent performance, have been widely used as the main backbone for mass transfer in metal catalysts. Concerning the carbon carrier structure, the porous structure and the high electrical conductivity facilitate material transport and electron transfer, respectively. Among, N-doped carbon materials have been widely adopted directly or indirectly in the field of catalysis, contributing to pyridinic-N and graphitic-N active sites boosting the electrochemically active surface area and charge transfer capacity of carbon materials [30–32]. The presence of N-containing groups effectively anchors the metal nanoparticles, stimulating the uniform dispersion of metal catalysts for improving ORR activity and stability [33]. Herein, we prepared Ag-Cu nanoparticles (NPs) to achieve quantitative production via hot-arc plasma technology, which presented a simple strategy to prepare the Ag-Cu/NPC catalysts with N-doped porous nanocarbon (NPC) wet grinding. The preparation of NPs with plasma evaporation technology undergoes a rapid cooling process facilitating the Ag-alloying to form the eutectic structure which changes the electronic structure. The requirement for catalyst mass transfer structure contains: (i) providing abundant diffusion channels to ensure oxygen diffusion and material transport, (ii) facilitating electron transfer. The designed and prepared N-PC 3D skeleton forms an optimal mass transfer structure for Ag-Cu NPs supporting the synthesis of high performances catalysts. This work combined morphological characterizations, catalytic performance and DFT calculations to explore the catalytic mechanism and ORR activity, providing a unique strategy for the economization of high performances Al-air battery cathode catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials synthesis Synthesis of Ag-Cu nanoparticles: Silver and copper metal pieces (mass ratio 3:1 and 1:1, expressed as Ag-Cu25 and Ag-Cu50, respectively) obtained composite metal targets by repeated melting under a vacuum atmosphere. As previously reported, the Ag-Cu composite NPs were produced by the plasma evaporation method, where the composite metal targets served as the anode and the tungsten rod as the cathode [34]. Mixed gas (Ar2 and H2 volume ratio 2:1) was incorporated into the equipment chamber as the working atmosphere. After a sequence of evaporation, condensation and passivation, the nanoparticles were collected with the notation of Ag-Cu25 Ns, Ag-Cu50 NPs. With the above method, Ag NPs and Cu NPs were prepared using silver and copper blocks as anode targets, respectively. Synthesis of NPC: The sodium citrate after drying (5 g), CNTs (0.3 g) and Melamine (1 g) were ball-milled for 3 h. They were placed in a porcelain vessel in a tube furnace and pyrolyzed at 850 °C under N2 for 2 h with temperature rise rate of 5 °C min−1 [35]. The pyrolysis products were acid washed with 0.1 M HCl, washed with deionized water and dried at 80 °C in a vacuum drying oven to obtain NPC. The PC was prepared by removing melamine from the precursor. Synthesis of catalysts: The above prepared NPs were used to prepare catalysts with NPC by wet milling method (ethanol), where the metal NPs mass ratio of 30 wt%. The various catalysts prepared were marked as Ag-Cu25/NPC, Ag-Cu50/NPC, Ag/NPC and Cu/NPC. Commercial superconducting carbon black carriers and Ag-Cu25 NPs were prepared for Ag-Cu25/C catalyst as comparison samples. 2.2 Material characterization Phase analysis of the crystal structure was recorded by X-ray powder diffractometer (XRD-6000) with Cu K α radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) at a sweep speed of 4° min−1 at 2 kV in the range of 30°–80°. Elemental composition content of NPs was determined via X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF-1800). The surface morphology was characterized using JSM-7900F divergence scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with a working voltage of 10 kV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) and element mapping images were obtained by field divergence transmission electron microscopy JEM-F200 at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Material defects and graphitization of NPC and PC carbon carriers pass the Raman shifts (DXR Microscope) analysis with a 780 nm laser excitation and spectral resolution <2 cm−1. Metal atom content in catalysts was recorded using inductively coupled plasma (ICP). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB XI+) was used to register the chemical state of the surface elements, following a monochromatic Al K α source (15 kV, 150 W) with a C 1s peak of 284.8 eV as calibration. The Braeuer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area and pore distribution were analyzed via Automatic physical adsorption instrument (AS-1-MP-11). 2.3 Electrocatalytic measurements Electrocatalytic measurements were performed with a conventional three-electrode system via electrochemical workstation (CHI 760) and rotating ring disk electrode equipment (RRDE-3A), where the RDE coated with catalyst as the working electrode, the Hg/HgO electrode (1 M KOH) as the reference electrode and the graphite rod as the counter electrode. All catalyst inks for electrochemical analysis were prepared from 4 mg catalyst, 470 μL anhydrous ethanol and 30 μL Nafion dispersed ultrasonically for 1 h. 5 μL of catalyst inks was applied to polished rotating disk electrode (RDE: 0.4 cm diameter) with a mass loading of 0.32 mg cm−2 for all catalysts. Before electrochemical characterization, O2 or N2 was injected into the 0.1 M KOH solution for 30 min to saturate. The oxygen reduction peak was measured from the cyclic voltammetry (CV) with a sweep rate of 50 mV s−1. The linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) polarization curves were recorded at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 at 1600 r min−1. The electron transfer numbers (n) and H2O2 yields were obtained based on the RRDE polarization curves according to the following equations. (1) H 2 O 2 y i e l d ( % ) = 200 × I R / N I R / N + I D (2) n = 4 × I D I R / N + I D where I D and I R are the disk and ring currents, respectively, and N is the ring collection efficiency (0.37). All potentials were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) depending on the Nernst equation. (3) E RHE = E Hg / H g O + 0.059 × p H + 0.098 The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) as measured with the CV double capacitance layer measurement (DLC) in the non-Falla region, was determined by the following equation. (4) E C S A = C d l + C s where C dl is the electrochemical double-layer capacitance, C s is the specific capacitance of the sample or the capacitance of an atomically smooth planar surface of the material per unit area. The stability performance of the catalyst was evaluated in the following two methods. The accelerated degradation test (ADT) was performed in continuous potential cycling between 0.5 and 1 V with a sweep rate of 100 mV s−1 for 5000 cycles. The chronoamperometric measurement (CA) was carried out at 0.46 V for 30000 s (1600 r min−1). 2.4 DFT computational details The DFT calculations were modeled from Material Studio (MS) software, conducted using the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). The electron exchange–correlation energy was recorded with the Perdew-Burke-Enrzerhof (PBE) parametrization of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA). The cutoff energy for plane wave expansion in atomic structure optimization was 500 eV, the criterion for total energy convergence of 10−5 eV, and the criterion for atomic force convergence was 0.05 eV Å−1. The Brillouin zone was sampled with 2 × 2 × 1 k-points from the Monkhorst-Pack method, while a 2 × 1 × 2 mesh was used for the density of states (DOS) calculations. The vacuum layers of Ag20 clusters and Ag15Cu5 clusters were set to 20 Å for determining the base model for the calculation. The four-electron pathway of ORR under alkaline conditions is as follows [31]. (5) *+O2 + H2O + e– → HOO* + OH– (6) HOO* + e– → O* + OH– (7) O* + H2O + e– → HO* + OH– (8) HO* + e– → OH– + * where * stands for the adsorption site on the catalysts surface. OOH*, O* and OH* are the ORR intermediates. 2.5 Al-air battery assembly As previously reported, the catalytic layer and air electrode were prepared in a conventional manner, where the catalyst loading was 3 mg cm−2. The aqueous Al-air batteries were assembled with a flow cycle test equipment (LT-OR1, reaction area 1 cm2), in which aluminum plates and air electrodes prepared with different catalysts functioned as the anode and cathode, respectively, and 6 M KOH operated as electrolyte (maintained at 65 °C). Open-circuit voltages and polarization curves of the Al-air batteries were monitored with the electrochemical workstation (CHI 660E). Documentation of the constant current discharge of Al-air batteries was achieved on LAND battery test system (CT3001B). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Materials synthesis and characterizations A range of silver-copper-based NPs was produced by the plasma evaporation method. The crystalline phases of the prepared different NPs were analyzed from XRD (Fig. 1 a). The characteristic peak positions of Ag NPs and Cu NPs are consistent with PDF#04-0783 and PDF#04-0836 standard cards, respectively. Ag-Cu NPs are dominated mainly by the Ag phase with weak peaks of Cu, which increases in intensity with the increase of Cu content. The characteristic peak positions of Ag-Cu NPs exhibit small angular shifts compared to the single-phase characteristic peak positions. The local area magnification about the Ag(1 1 1) peaks vicinity in Fig. 1(b) shows that the Ag(1 1 1) peak positions of Ag-Cu NPs are shifted to the right due to the solid solution of Cu with a smaller atomic radius in the Ag lattice [36]. Where the offset angle of Ag-Cu25 NPs is 0.52°, which is greater than that of Ag-Cu50 (0.44°). The Cu(1 1 1) peak positions of Ag-Cu NPs exhibit an evident shift to higher angles, which also indicates that Ag and Cu exist in the form of mutual solid solution. HAADF-STEM image and the corresponding element mapping of the Ag-Cu NPs in Fig. 1(d) further demonstrate that the Ag-Cu uniform dispersion and solidly soluble in each other. To further explore the Ag-Cu phases, we obtain the lattice constants of 0.40384 and 0.40491 nm for Ag-Cu25 and Ag-Cu50 NPs, respectively, which are smaller than the Ag (0.40862 nm), using the Jade software. The solid solubility of Cu is calculated according to Vigard’s law: a = a A g + a C u - a A g x + Δ a , where a Ag represents the lattice constant of Ag (0.40862 nm), a Cu represents the lattice constant of Cu (0.36153 nm), △a represents the modified value of the lattice constant (0.00272 nm) [37]. The Ag-Cu25 NPs possess a higher Cu extended solid solution (15.93 at.%) than Ag-Cu50 (13.65 at.%), indicating a higher Ag-Cu eutectic composition. This conclusion is consistent with the results of Ag(1 1 1) peak shift. The atomic mass ratios of Ag-Cu25 and Ag-Cu50 NPs were recorded using XRF (Table S1), and the results are basically consistent with the material design. The mass fraction of Cu in the Ag-Cu NPs is slightly reduced compared to the metal targets, probably owing to the higher melting point of Cu and slower evaporation rate. The solid solubility of Cu in Ag-Cu NPs is much smaller than the Cu content, indicating that separate Ag and Cu phases are also present in the structure. This anomaly for Ag-Cu NPs with a very weak solid solution is attributed to the plasma preparation method. All Ag-Cu-based NPs prepared from plasma exhibit excellent dispersion (Fig. 2 a–d). Ag NPs with smallest particle size (119.91 nm) present a certain degree of cross-linking between particles. Cu-based NPs exhibit homogeneous spherical shapes and high dispersion. The particle size of Ag-Cu NPs is between that of Ag and Cu NPs. The particle size of Ag-Cu25 NPs (121.33 nm) is closer to that of Ag, which has a larger specific surface area, exposing more active sites and facilitating oxygen reduction reactions. EDS analysis was used to verify the consistency of the composition of Ag-Cu NPs with different particle sizes. The results of the EDS analysis in selected regions with different particle size NPs (Fig. S1, Table S2) suggest the compositional homogeneity of the plasma-prepared Ag-Cu NPs, and the elemental content is consistent with the XRF results. The TEM images of Ag-Cu25 NPs (Fig. 2e) also demonstrate that the plasma-prepared NPs possess highly dispersed properties. The Ag-Cu25 NPs features an oxide layer about 1 nm thick, resulting from the passage of air during the passivation process (Fig. 2f, Fig. S2). The HR-TEM image (Fig. 2g) corresponding to the local magnification of the NPs edge region displays the characterization of the fine structure. Selected A and B areas at two distinctly different lattice stripes were available for high-resolution to real-time Fourier (FFT) analysis. The lattice spacing in A and B regions are 0.2346 and 0.1806 nm, corresponding to the Ag(1 1 1) and Cu(2 0 0) crystal planes, respectively, which adequately verifies the presence of Ag and Cu single phases at the outer layers of the Ag-Cu25 NPs. The growth mechanism of Ag-Cu25 NPs is further explored, which is schematically generated as shown in Fig. 2(h). The discharge between the two poles leads to extremely high temperatures (over 10000 °C) in the arc region. The Ag-Cu composite target evaporates instantly, forming gaseous atoms. The gaseous atoms move freely out of the arc region and experience rapid quenching, which condenses under the action of Ar gas [38]. According to the Ag-Cu phase diagram, the Cu composition at the eutectic point is 28.5 wt.%. Under non-equilibrium solidification conditions, the Ag-Cu25 liquid metal in the vicinity of the eutectic point will undergo pseudo-eutectic reactions at 780 °C, all transforming into α phases (Ag-rich) and β phases (Cu-rich), which do not readily form compounds. With the decrease in temperature and solid solution, Cu and Ag elements are precipitated from the α and β phases, respectively, which diffuse around the eutectic phase to form separate Ag and Cu. Finally, rapid coagulation causes the eutectic structure to solidify at the core, resulting in the presence of an abundant eutectic structure and a high solid solution, where two types of core–shell structured nanoparticles cluster to form Ag-Cu25 NPs. The NPC carriers were prepared from pyrolysis method with high specific surface area (400 m2 g−1), abundant micropores (average pore size: 2.77 nm) and remarkable transport channels (Fig. 3 a and b, Fig. S3). Transport channels facilitate the diffusion of oxygen and the transport of the products. Compared with PC (Fig. S4), NPC exhibits more folds since nitrogen doping increases the defects in the carbon material which favors the catalytic activity. The CNT scaffold supports the NPC and the 2D structure transformed into a 3D interconnected hierarchical porous structure. NPC with a 3D structure provides high conductivity enabling rapid electron transfer. Raman characterization of different mass transfer carriers (Fig. 3d) reveals that the integral areas I G/I D value of NPC (1.18) is much smaller than that of PC (I G/I D = 3.24), indicating the presence of a large number of defects in carbon [39]. The relatively high G peak reveals a high degree of graphitization and excellent electrical conductivity. This conclusion is consistent with the reflection of the material properties and morphology. NPC supported highly active Ag-Cu-based metal NPs catalysts were prepared via wet milling method. To further explore the performance of the NPC carriers, the interfacial charge transfer characteristics of the different carrier catalysts were analyzed with EIS (Fig. S5). The simulation analysis of the equivalent circuit (Fig. S6, Table S3) suggests that Ag-Cu25/NPC possesses the minimum transfer resistance (R ct = 87.87 Ω) and Warburg impedance (Z w = 16.12), attributed to the high conductivity and the abundance diffusion channels, respectively [15]. Meanwhile, the charge transfer characteristics of Ag-Cu catalysts outperform Pt/C. HAADF-STEM image and the corresponding element mapping of the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst in Fig. 3(c) further evidence that uniform loading of Ag-Cu25 NPs on NPC. The content of highly active nanoparticles in the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalysts was measured utilizing ICP, as shown in Table S4. The mass content of Ag and Cu is 22.32 and 7.15 wt.%, respectively, with a mass ratio about 3:1, which demonstrates the rationality of the material design and preparation. The mass ratio of Ag-Cu25 NPs is 29.47 wt.%, close to the 30 wt.% added during the preparation, indicating that NPC offers excellent anchoring properties. The chemical elemental composition and valence states of the catalyst and NPS were investigated with XPS. The high-resolution Ag 3d spectrum of different Ag-based NPs (Fig. 2e) all consist of two predominant peaks, corresponding to Ag 3d 5/2 and Ag 3d 3/2, respectively [40], and each peak can be decomposed into characteristic peaks of metal Ag and Ag2O [41,42]. Further examination of the variation of different Ag-based NPs Ag 3d 3/2 and Ag 3d 5/2 suggests that the decrease in level peak binding energies is due to the electronic structure change, which leads to an upward shift of the d-band center [43]. The Cu+ ion is difficult to distinguish from zero-valent Cu via XPS, whereas Cu2+ provides easy identification [44]. The high-resolution Cu 2p spectra as shown in Fig. 3(g). The characteristic peaks at 934.0 and 954.1 eV correspond to Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2, respectively [45]. The remaining two peaks (943.6 and 962.6 eV) belong to the Cu2+ characteristic peaks, due to the production of copper oxide during the passivation of NPs. High-resolution O 1s spectrum evidences the presence of Ag2O and CuO (in Fig. S7), assigned to the formation of oxide layers during passivation. The XPS results disclose that the Ag-Cu NPs structure modifies the electronic structure of Ag which may facilitate activity. The high-resolution C 1s spectrum (Fig. 3h) mimics three distinct peaks corresponding to the CC (284.8 eV), CN (285.6 eV) and CO/CO (289.1 eV) bonds, respectively [46]. The high nitrogen content of 6.55 at.% effectively anchors the metal nanoparticles to promote uniform dispersion of high activity NPs (Fig. S8, Table S5). The fitted high-resolution N 1s spectrum (Fig. 3i) indicates three separate peaks belonging to pyridine N (399.3 eV), pyridine N (400.7 eV), and graphite N (403.1 eV), respectively [2,47,48]. The proportions of the three different types of nitrogen are illustrated in Table S5. The highest percentage of pyridine nitrogen is 66.5 at.%, which increases the activity of the mass transfer carbon carrier to facilitate the reaction rate [49,50]. The presence of graphite N improves the electrical conductivity favoring electron transfer [31]. NPC exhibits abundant mesopores, superior conductivity, and excellent activity, providing a comfortably matchable mass transfer structure for highly reactive Ag-Cu NPs. 3.2 ORR performance of catalysts The ORR performance of various catalysts was explored with a three-electrodes system in 0.1 M KOH alkaline media. The CV curves of all catalysts feature significant oxygen reduction peaks in O2-saturated electrolyte compared to N2-saturated, as shown in Fig. 4 (a). The Ag-Cu25/NPC achieves the highest ORR peak potential of 0.80 V among the prepared catalysts, which is 50 mV lower than that of Pt/C (0.84 V). The ORR peak potential of Cu/NPC (0.78 V) is higher than that of Ag/NPC (0.72 V), while Ag-Cu25/NPC (0.77 V) is intermediate between them. The oxygen reduction peaks of NPC and PC are 0.68 and 0.66 V, respectively. The CV curves indicate that the intervention of Cu significantly improves the catalytic potential of Ag, and the N-doped carbon carrier is more favorable for the ORR reaction. Fig. 4(b) examines the LSV curves of various catalysts with 1600 r min−1. Excluding Pt/C (E 1/2 = 0.86 V), the Ag-Cu25/NPC exhibits remarkable catalytic activity with the highest half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.81 V (Fig. S9). The limiting diffusion current densities (J L) of the Ag-based catalysts are all greater than those of Cu/NPC, implying rapid reaction kinetics. The ORR kinetic electron transfer pathways and H2O2 yields of various catalysts are evaluated applying the RRDE technique (Fig. 4c, Fig. S10a, Table S6). The average electron transfer number (n) of the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst is 3.90, which is almost consistent with Pt/C (n = 3.89), suggesting the ORR reaction favors 4-electron transfer. The result is consistent with the electron transfer number calculated from the K-L equation (Fig. S11). The corresponding H2O2 yield is suppressed below 7.93%, which is lower than Pt/C (10.50%). Tafel curves of different catalysts are used to explore ORR kinetic properties intensively. The Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst offers the low Tafel slope, consistent with Pt/C, implicates a faster ORR kinetic reaction rate [51]. Tafel slope of the Cu/NPC catalyst is much higher than that of Ag/NPC, indicating a more retarded reaction rate, while fully supporting the conclusion reflected from the J L values. The intrinsic activity of the catalyst active sites is further estimated via the ECSA, based on the double layer capacitance (C dl) in non-Falla region (Fig. 4e, Figs. S10b, S12). Among Table S6, the Ag-Cu25/NPC possesses the highest ECSA of 1377 m2 g−1, indicating outstanding intrinsic activity for ORR [52,53]. Based on the fact that the Ag-Cu25/NPC and Pt/C catalysts have similar Tafel slope values, the Turnover Frequency (TOF) and mass activity of the two catalysts are further measured. This work is based on all metal atoms as active sites for obtaining TOF values according to Eq. (S4) [54]. The TOF value for Ag-Cu25/NPC is 0.012 s−1, which is lower than Pt/C (0.039 s−1), indicating that the low utilization of the Ag-Cu25 active site is attributed to the low number of active sites exposed (Table S7). The mass activity of the Ag-Cu25/NPC and Pt/C is 13.1 and 15.0 A g−1, respectively, which illustrated the favorable ORR catalytic activity of the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst. The stability and durability of catalysts are also important strategies to evaluate electrocatalytic performance [47]. Fig. 4(f) records the LSV curves of the Ag catalyst before and after 5000 cycles from the ADT test. The negative shift of E 1/2 (ΔE 1/2) of Ag-Cu25/NPC is 14 mV, which is less than Pt/C (ΔE 1/2 = 30 mV, Fig. 4g), indicating excellent stability. AC test documents the durability of catalyst materials in response to timing current changes for 30000 s (Fig. 4h). The Ag-Cu25/NPC maintains an initial current value of 82.2%, which is much higher than Pt/C (72.5%) with the same conclusion as the ADT test. The superior durability of Ag-Cu25/NPC catalysts maybe due to the interaction between different metals and an oxide film on the nanoparticle surface that effectively inhibits metal dissolution. To further determine the role of eutectic alloying on the ORR activity in Ag-Cu25 NPs, DFT calculations were performed. Based on the morphological characterization results, we developed computational models for Ag20 and Ag15Cu5 clusters corresponding to Ag NPs and Ag-Cu25 NPs, respectively, in Fig. 5 (a and b). Fig. 5(c) illustrates the free energy diagram for the four-electron oxygen reduction pathway on Ag NPs and Ag-Cu25 NPs in alkaline media at U = 0.46 V. The rate-determining step (RDS) for both models is the first step (from O2 to *OOH), dominating the ORR overpotential [55]. Specifically, Ag-Cu25 NPs possess the smallest limiting reaction barrier (1.02 eV), indicating exposing that eutectic alloying increases ORR activity [56,57]. The ability of Ag-Cu25 NPs to desorb O* and OH* is slightly weaker than that of Ag NPs, due to the poor intrinsic desorption of Cu. It is speculated that the weaker than optimal catalytic performance of Ag-Cu50 due to the excess of Cu atoms and the lower eutectic structure. The DOS calculation is performed on Ag NPs and Ag-Cu25 NPs models to investigate electronic effects (Fig. 5d). The d-band center of Ag-Cu25 NPs (−2.87 eV) is closer to the Fermi energy level (0 eV) than that of Ag NPs (−3.17 eV), which enhances the adsorption energy of oxygen-containing substances and elevates the ORR intrinsic catalytic activity [24,58]. In summary, the active sites of the catalysts will be further defined. Electrochemical three-electrode measurements indicate that both Ag and Cu nanoparticles are effective active sites. DFT suggests that the d-band center of Ag-Cu25 NPs is shifted upwards with minimal limiting reaction barrier, enhancing the overall catalytic activity. The excellent synergistic catalytic performance of Ag-Cu25/NPC is further clarified through recording the polarization curves of comparative Ag&Cu(3:1)/NPC catalyst (Figs. S13, S9). The excellent catalytic activity of Ag-Cu/NPC in ORR is attributed to the following: (i) Ag and Cu exert their respective catalytic properties, synergistically improving the adsorption of Ag and the desorption of Cu. (ii) The d-band center of Ag-Cu25 NPs with high melting point is closer to the Fermi energy, which facilitates the ORR reaction. (iii) NPC with catalytic activity exhibits excellent anchoring of NPs ability to provide more active sites. 3.3 Applications in Al-air battery The above electrocatalytic performances and DFT conclusions both indicate that the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst possesses advantageous ORR activity. However, the reaction rate of Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst in highly concentrated alkaline electrolytes would be essential for device applications. Assemble aqueous Al-air batteries based on Ag/NPC and Ag-Cu25/NPC catalysts explore the electrochemical performance of the devices. Open-circuit voltage was recorded after the assembled Al-air batteries were placed for 20 min in Fig. 6 (a). Open-circuit voltage of 1.89 V for Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst is higher than that of Ag/NPC catalyst (1.83 V). The Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst exhibits remarkable open-circuit voltage attributed to the strong oxygen adsorption capacity of Ag-Cu NPs and multiple airway transmission channels provided with NPC. The power density curves of the two Al-air batteries were obtained from documenting the polarization curves (Fig. 6b). The maximum power density value of 193 mW cm−2 for the air electrode with Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst is credited to the remarkable reaction rate and mass transfer structure. Fig. 6(c) illustrates the constant current discharge of different Al-air batteries at different current densities from 10–150 mA cm−2. Both aluminum-air batteries display splendid rate performance. Returning to low current discharge after high current cycling, the voltage can reach the initial value. The air electrode with Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst features higher voltage values at different current densities compared to the Ag/NPC catalyst, where the voltage achieves about 1 V at high current densities of 150 mA cm−2. The high voltage characteristic at high current densities is a critical indicator for energy device applications. The higher voltage of the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst benefits from the introduction of Cu to modify the oxygen absorption capacity of Ag. Based on the Chinese industry standard (YST 1515-2021), Fig. 6(d) demonstrates the constant current discharge curve of various Al-air batteries at 120 mA cm−2 for 2 h. The energy density of battery is obtained according to the mass of aluminum consumed in 2 h of discharge. All batteries possess favorable cycling performance with high voltage retention efficiency. The energy density of Al-air battery with Ag-Cu25/NPC reaches 2412 W h kg−1, which is higher than that of Ag/NPC (2043 W h kg−1). The discharge durability test of the Al-air battery relied on mechanical charging to achieve. Al-air battery with Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst can maintain 120 h of discharge at 100 mA cm−2 with mechanical recharge, which replaces the aluminum anode (mechanical recharge) four times in Fig. 6(e). The air electrode with Ag-Cu25/NPC provides excellent cyclability and durability with a voltage retention rate of over 93% after 120 h. The comprehensive electrochemical performance of Ag-Cu25/NPC is superior to some of the reported catalysts (in Table S8), which is attributed to the high activity of the Ag-Cu25 NPs and the optimal mass transfer structure. The above assembled Al-air battery with Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst realizes the application of the device. Two assembled batteries are connected in series as the power supply for the LED screen, where the LED screen operates at a voltage of 1–5 V. Fig. 7 (a–d) present photographs of the LED screen in the original state and at different moments after operation. The LED screen continues to work for 16 h with essentially the same brightness, confirming the activity and durability of the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst. Theoretically designing the Al-air battery pack as multiple batteries in series to reach the rated voltage of the appliance will allow it to work properly. We believe that the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst has high electrical conductivity, abundant transport channels and excellent oxygen adsorption, enabling the high electrochemical performance of Al-air batteries. 4 Conclusions In summary, we successfully prepared highly reactive Ag-Cu NPs with high eutectic phase and uniform dispersion structure that exhibits unique electronic structures and enhanced oxygen adsorption capabilities. DFT calculations suggest that Ag-Cu25 NPs facilitate the adsorption of O2 molecules, which accelerates the reaction kinetics. High electrical conductivity and abundant mesoporous channels of N-PC 3D skeleton affords optimal mass transfer carriers for highly active Ag-Cu NPs. The Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst manifests excellent ORR activity and promising stability in alkaline media. Al-air battery with Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst exhibits outstanding electrochemical performances, with a power density of 191 mW cm−2, high current sustained stable output high voltage of 120 h, demonstrating the substantial potential to replace commercial Pt/C. coredata.dc:description: Efficient, stable and economical catalysts play a crucial role in enhancing the kinetics of slow oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) in Aluminum-air batteries. Among the potential next-generation candidates, Ag catalysts are promising due to their high activity and low cost, but weaker oxygen adsorption has hindered industrialization. To address this bottleneck, Ag-alloying has emerged as a principal strategy. In this work, we successfully prepared Ag-Cu nanoparticles (NPs) with a rich eutectic phase and uniform dispersion structure using plasma evaporation. The increased solid solution of Ag and Cu led to changes in the electronic structure, resulting in an upward shift of the d-band center, which significantly improved oxygen adsorption. The combination of Ag and Cu in the NPs synergistically enhanced the adsorption of Ag and the desorption of Cu. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that Ag-Cu25 NPs exhibited the smallest limiting reaction barrier, leading to increased ORR activity. To further optimize the catalyst's performance, we utilized N-doped porous nanocarbon (N-PC) with high electrical conductivity and abundant mesoporous channels as the support for the Ag-Cu NPs. The N-PC support provided optimal mass transfer carriers for the highly active Ag-Cu25 NPs. As a result, the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst displayed excellent ORR activity in alkaline media, with a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.82 V. Furthermore, the Al-air battery incorporating the Ag-Cu25/NPC catalyst exhibited outstanding electrochemical performance. It demonstrated high open-circuit voltages of 1.89 V and remarkable power densities of 193 mW cm−2. The battery also sustained a high current output and maintained a stable high voltage for 120 hours under mechanical charging, showcasing its significant potential for practical applications.
